reviewText: I've certainly enjoyed almost all of Liev's previous performances and was unprepared for this disaster.  The one positive about Ray Donovan is that it is not boring, but, in a weird way, fascinating in its awfulness. Jon Voight transcends his bravura stint in Anaconda, with overacting that is completely satisfying to those who appreciate "so bad it's good". Voight actually gets a run for his money from Ray's wife, whose favorite word is the 'F" bomb, but not in a good way.  One star, BUT highly recommended.
Title: Ray Donovan: The First Season

reviewText: This is one rich story. My wife doesn't like stories that don't have at least one perfect character with excellent morals, high character, and heroic strength to deal with less perfect humans. I think she misses a lot. So, I was on my own with this. It is a fine investment. The hero of this show, is the show. It's a super hero, without dragons or robots. I completed it today. Beautiful.
summary: In Spring of 2014, we are just reviewing the tv show
Title: Ray Donovan: The First Season

reviewText: Started out well but falls fast. Let me start with the pro's.1. Great cast!2. A unique story idea with believable characters that have believable faults and flaws.3. Dark humor.The con's1. Storytelling flaws. Including way out there and unbelievable plot points. Like Bunchy gettin over a million dollars from the Catholic church in 2013 from being molested in his youth. Statute limitations out the window.2. The "fixes" are very convenient.3. Minor spoiler. The priest that molested Bunchy is in the same city as he. The church just sent him a check knowing they're in the same city. Again plot convenient.4. Rays dad talks his way out of situations too frequently and too conveniently.5. Way too much time spent on his daughter's relationship with the kid from next door.6. Not enough time spent telling the stories of the more interesting characters.7. Very bad accents.  They try too hard to sound like there from South Boston. They've been in California for twenty years, half their life, but still say caaa instead of car?As you can see the cons win. Which is to say we, the viewer, lose. If you watch shows and movies uncritically,  you will probably enjoy this show.
Title: Ray Donovan: The First Season

reviewText: Worlds collide in this drama that combines crime, family, and hollyweird. Ray Donovan is a man with a damaged family, a decent family of his own, and connections deep in Hollywood's rich and famous. He fixes things that movie and sports star do wrong, including ending up in bed with dead people and other sordid acts. His father, Mickey, shows up after doing 20 years in prison back east. Uh, oh! Mickey brings the past with him, a murder Ray covered up years ago. It's all skidding into the abyss for Ray as the harder he tries to fix things the worse they get. The show launches with several awesome episodes. It slows down in the middle of the season as we get caught up in Ray's kids' troubles. But it winds up with a heck of a bang. Stay with it. The acting is brilliant, especially from Schreiber, Paula Malcomson, and John Voight. This is how good TV can be.
Title: Ray Donovan: The First Season

reviewText: EXCELLENT ACTING BY ALL CONCERNED.  LIEV VERY CREDITABLE AND JON VOIGHT AS HIS FATHER HAS A SUPERB  ROLE IN THIS SERIES.  IT IS BELIEVABLE.  IT IS ACTION PACKED AND THERE ARE VARYING STORIES GOING ON THROUGHOUT.  GOOD WRITING!

reviewText: CONCRETE......HEAVY.........AND TWISTED IN SOME PERVERSE WAY
Title: Ray Donovan: The First Season

reviewText: This is a compelling and offbeat series with the terrific (stage and screen actor) Liev Schreiber in the title role, and Jon Voight as his father who was just released from prison after 20 years.  Breaks many conventions, not nearly as predictable as many feature films, and with rough language, rough action, and we think dialogue more real and believable than in many feature films or TV shows.Voight is perhaps best remembered for Midnight Cowboy in 1969, but actually won the Academy Award for Best Actor not for that, but for Coming Home in 1978 with Jane Fonda and Bruce Dern.  Today, he has considerable notoriety for very conservative politics and as the father of stunningly beautiful actress Angelina Jolie.  In any event, Voight is still a terrific actor.  (In recent years, he was particularly good in the film based on John Grisham's novel, The Rainmaker," with Matt Damon.  Worth a look!)Ray Donovan is a "fixer" in Hollywood.  He's closely associated here with a character played by Elliott Gould, who is always good.  Ray's wife Abby is played by Paula Malcomson, who is excellent in the role.  Also look for Steven "Rocky" Bauer, who played Al Pacino's impossibly handsome sidekick in Brian de Palma's Scarface, over thirty years ago.  Bauer is Ray Donovan's sidekick in this new series.As we don't currently have Showtime, we've been watching this on a modestly priced pay per view on Amazon over the 'net, streaming to our BluRay player, and from there onto an HD TV.  Great fun.  Something different.  Season 1 is also available now on amazon as a set on DVD and BluRay.
Title: Ray Donovan: The First Season

reviewText: Griity, soulful, and real. Live Shriever and Jon Voight are out of this world good in this Showtime drama. The music, the acting, and the plotline are all top notch. Each episode leaves you anxiously waiting to see what happens next. What a great story arc...
summary: One of the most compelling TV series ever.
Title: Ray Donovan: The First Season

reviewText: Nothing ever written as well as this deep emotional multi-issue dysfunctional family drama. Its complex, fraught with lingering residues of the past, frightening, a totally perfect depiction of Boston people (his wife is the perfect thin-lipped nasty Southie girl), violent, with excellent character development (about time Jon Voight finally did some real acting), immoral, blasphemous, plenty of twists and tricky turns, and most of all keeps you on the crest of the story all the way through to the end. This is hard core drama yet doesn't leave you with a tear in your eye even as hard as it is to imagine dealing with such a myriad of burdens. To say more is to cheat you out of one of the best series made to date. If they never produce another season, this one would is a perfect encapsulation and a stand alone masterpiece theater (without the Brits). Enjoy.
summary: Ray of Light for a Dark Soul
Title: Ray Donovan: The First Season

reviewText: Sunday afternoon, checking Amazon for new releases, and up pops Ray Donovan.  Never heard of it.  But there's Liev Schreiver's face in the thumbnail, looking seriously cool as he's clearly hiding some serious secrets.  Am hooked by first episode and hooked hard.  So hooked that binge-watch of entire season is necessary; more excited about watching this than Sunday night's latest episode of Game of Thrones, a dilemma I could not imagine ever occurring.Writing and story sparkle and snap with fresh.  Characters and how they're played are fascinating.  Shouting and clichés are simply not necessary and very rarely used.  Audience is rarely made to suffer through over-dramatic acting.  The teenagers can become tedious, but that's true in real life as well.So, what's Ray Donovan about?  Ray Donovan is a fixer with a very small crew so trusted that few words are necessary to get the point across.  He's also a family man with the darkest of demons haunting him and his own siblings.  Was not a fan of Jon Voight, but the ease in which he inhabits the complete lack of conscience simply cannot be denied.  One favorite character is the female member of Donovan's crew; this woman is ridiculously cool and blew my mind; more than once she had me cheering YAY!All manner of killers, crazies, weaklings, predators, bullies and honest people cross Donovan's path; to become a voyeur of this madness is irresistible.  Bravo to director, writers and actors; Ray Donovan is positively brilliant.
summary: Made me miss Game of Thrones
Title: Ray Donovan: The First Season

Title: Ray Donovan: The First Season

reviewText: On the surface, Ray Donovan is a slick thriller about a powerful LA law firm and it's "fixer" of major Hollywood problems and complications. Ray Donovan is who you call if you're a pro basketball player who has woken up in bed with a dead girl or a major Hollywood star who has gotten caught, again, with, a transsexual hooker. Somehow these two problems end up canceling each other out in an outrageous way that actually makes a sick kind of sense. But the complications don't end at Ray's professional life, his personal life and the lives of his extended family are rife with problems. Ray(played by Liev Screiber) his wife are  working class transplants from Boston who play the Hollywood game at cocktail parties at their Calabasas home but they aren't above breaking the fingers of the man who has denied their daughter entrance into an exclusive private school.The major plot point revolves around the release and return of Ray's mobster father from prison back east. He is brilliantly played here by John Voigt and is out for retribution, It's Ray who helped put him away twenty years before. Complicating matters are Ray's three brothers. There's Terry, an ex-boxer with Parkinson's and Bunchy an alcoholic and survivor of sexual abuse. What is most interesting about these characters and series is the mix of the east coast mob/crime drama mixed with the modern world of money and celebrity. For all of Ray's sophistication, he's not above taking a bat to someone. I hate comparisons but it's a bit like Entourage crossed with Goodfellas. And as mentioned, the cast is top notch with great character actors and stars like Elliot Gould. Definitely something to binge watch!
Title: Ray Donovan: The First Season

reviewText: A well-considered tale which never gets ponderous, written with a genius for cliche-avoidance that puts those responsible at some sort of Delta Force level in La La Land, where the whole damned place is festooned with cliches like a mighty Tennessee cavern is with stalactites and bat guano.  I've been "watching real good" thru several episodes, and that fine pro Mr Schreiber has got his A-Game cooking, not a sloppy move, a seasoned actor giving Mr Donovan a dignity and a goodness which is strikingly melded with his adult resignation to a career which rewards him well, hence compelling him as a businessman to just do his job, around people who not only vacuum all the energy out of a room, but all the honor as well.  Because Mr Donovan has a high bar regarding his honor which he protects quietly, even when the power of money and those with money force his hand."Ray Donovan" is a quiet stunner of a show.  All the pros are here.
Title: Ray Donovan: The First Season

reviewText: A very good series, kept interest, dark in mood, excellent acting
Title: Ray Donovan: The First Season

Title: Ray Donovan: The First Season

Title: Ray Donovan: The First Season

reviewText: Ever find yourself in a mess and wish you had someone to help you out? If you are rich, a celebrity and live in LA you have Ray Donovan. He's a 'Fixer', that's his job, which made me wonder, how do you prepare for this kind of profession?Liv Schreiber plays Ray, a dark, brooding man who is called at all hours to fix someone's problems. He s employed by Goldman and Drexter, a law firm. This is a tough job, very physical, often employing guns and the like. Fists fly, threats are made. Often the situations are sexual in nature, and Ray knows how to fix everyone's problems. He has a staff who are the best at their work, and the insurance the law firm must have to cover them is probably in the millions.Ray has a family, wife, Abby,  played by Paula Malcomson, two children, a boy and girl. They are Boston Irish and all came to LA to hide from Ray's father, Mickey, played byJon Voight. The dysfunction in this family is like no other. Mickey is said to be responsible for his daughter's suicide, and has killed a Priest. It sounds like Mickey was part of the Boston Mafia. He went to prison for twenty years, and was let out early, ostensibly to rat on Ray for the FBI.  One happy family, once Mickey journeys to LA to join Ray's brothers at their boxing establishment.Each episode, and there are 12, opens with a client needing Ray's services. Ray and his wife are always on the 'outs', and he often stays in an apartment in LA. Abby, the wife, seems innocent of what kind of person Ray is, which is difficult to swallow. The biggest complaint I have is of Abby's false Boston accent, drives me crazy, it is so noticeable, and she is the only one who fakes the accent.The interaction between Ray and his father is often grim and turns personal at times. Liev Schreiber and Jon Voight are superb as father and son. Great acting and believable situations. Top notch writing makes this series one to watch. A second year was picked up recently, so Ray Donovan will be around.Recommended. prisrob 09-15-13
Title: Ray Donovan: The First Season

reviewText: So far I've only watched episodes 1-3 and am looking forward to screening the remaining nine.  Extremely well produced, directed and acted series; deserving of many Emmy awards.

Title: Ray Donovan: The First Season

reviewText: "Ray Donovan" is sort of the Irish equivalent of "The Sopranos," only much slimier and more debased.  Sleaze is the name of the game here, as Liev Schreiber plays a Hollywood fixer (transplanted from the Irish slums of Boston) whose days are given over to brutally intimidating people with threat of violence in order to get celebrity movie stars out of sordid, potentially career-threatening jams.  How this never remotely attracts the attention of the police is never touched upon.  And the "celebrity" actors have about as much charisma as a pile of old newspapers.  Inexplicably, Jon Voight, portraying Ray's father, finds himself a participant in this trash.  And Eliot Gould occasionally wanders in and out of the plotline, a glum Jew looking like a deer caught in the headlights. To give you an idea of how debased this series is -- Ray Donovan actually hires someone to kill his own father, and himself kills a priest whom he accuses of having molested his brother when they were growing up in Boston.  The rest of the Donovans are equally low-class sleazy, including his lowlife brothers, who operate out of a seedy gym.  With characters this debauched, repulsive and debased, how are we supposed to care about them?  The series was apparently created by Ann Biderman, who cut her teeth writing for "NYPD Blue" back in the day.  The writing is very weak in terms of exposition -- it is impossible to discern Eliot Gould's relation to the Ray Donovan character, even after an entire season of episodes.  This should have been made clear from the get-go.  If you enjoy wallowing in gratuitous sleaze, this series is for you.  If you are not a bottom-feeder, beware.
Title: Ray Donovan: The First Season

reviewerName: Sailing In The VI "R. S. Maris"
reviewText: If I were able to give ratings based on Categories, I'd give Liev Schreiber all 5 stars. I'm happy for him that he finally got a leading man role in something. He's a towering presence, both physically and emotionally.I knew going in, however, that I wouldn't be able to hang. The drama was just going to be too depressing. That's why I watched only the pilot. I might have been moved to stay for those shows which featured him doing his job as a Fixer a la Mr. Wolfe in "Pulp Fiction", like the pilot.
Title: Ray Donovan: The First Season

reviewText: There is a lot of back story that has to be told, so it takes a couple episodes for Ray Donovan to get going.  But it has slowly became this years best new show, and I think it will be a hit for many years.  The acting is some of the best I have seen, there are so many talented people on this show.  Give this show a chance.
Title: Ray Donovan: The First Season

reviewText: This show was well put together and Live Schrieber is an excellent actor. The show revolves around Ray Donovan who is a fixer for the stars. Any situation he seems to be able to fix but his family is another thing altogether. His father Mikey Donovan is excellently played by Jon Voight! It's just an incredibly well put together series and I can't wait for Season 2 on Showtime!

reviewText: Paula Malcomson, as Ray's wife, should have been killed off by the writers in the first episode.  Women may enjoy watching her constantly emasculating her husband, but men want that bitch put down.  I'm not saying something over the top, just her car going off a 500 foot cliff with Ray's father at 100mph, with the trunk packed with C4 and ball bearings, and the car exploding in a ball of flames leaving a crater the size of the Arizona meteorite impact.But we all know the writers would simply re-introduce her character as her evil twin sister, who's even more of a nagging, whining, bitch.Otherwise, I really like the show and would give it Five Stars.
summary: If You Like Wives Who Are Bitches, Then This Is For You
Title: Ray Donovan: The First Season
